Brooklyn Historical Society
Elizabeth Payne drawings of Fort Greene Park
Payne, Elizabeth
Payne, Elizabeth
2015.024
1.25 Linear Feet in one box
1985 The collection consists of twenty three works on paper in pen and ink by the artist Elizabeth Payne from her Fort Greene (Autumn) 1985 series. 0050
Scope and Contents
The collection consists of twenty three works on paper in pen and ink from the series Fort Greene Park (Autumn) 1985 by artist Elizabeth Payne:
#2050 Park perimeter (Washington Park, street), brownstones
#2053 Excised tree and bench
#2054 Excised tree and bench
#2055 Excised tree
#2056 Excised tree
#2057 Excised tree
#2058 Trees and temple/building
#2059 Temple/building
#2060 Temple/building, orange trees
#2061 View of Manhattan from the top of the hill
#2062 Crypt entrance, left side
#2063 Crypt entrance, right side
#2064 Crypt entrance back left
#2065 Crypt entrance, back right
#2066 View of steps, crypt, monument column
#2067 Myrtle Avenue side of park, left, with shadows
#2068 Myrtle Avenue side of park, right, no shadows
#2069 Park bench, trees, Manhattan Bridge
#2070 Park lamppost, trees
#2071 Bare tree
#2072 Crypt entrance, gray
#2052 Trees and Martyrs Monument
#2051 Trees and brownstone houses
Processing Information
Minimally processed to the collection level.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of Elizabeth Payne, 2015.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); Elizabeth Payne drawings of Fort Greene Park, 2015.024, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright held by the Brooklyn Historical Society. Permission to publish or reproduce must be secured from the Brooklyn Historical Society.
Conditions Governing Access
Open to researchers without restriction.
Biographical Note
Elizabeth Payne (1948-) is a fine artist who grew up in the Midwest United States. She attended Webster College in St. Louis, Missouri, where she began to concentrate on fine art painting, and received a Masters of Arts degree from Hunter College, New York, New York, and a Bachelor of Fine Arts from the San Francisco Art Institute, San Francisco, California. A painting of hers was part of the 1975 Biennial Exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Her work while living in Brooklyn and working towards her Master of Arts degree at Hunter College evolved away from minimal abstraction and included portraits of her female artist friends and series relating to Brooklyn. In 1993, Ms. Payne moved to Yoakum, Texas and her work became more color-field related. In 2012, she joined the Gentileschi Aegis Gallery Association ("GAGA"), a non-profit organization founded by Sylvia Benitez. Her work has been exhibited in museums and galleries beginning in the early 1970s.
Sources
Brooklyn Museum. 2015. "Elizabeth Payne." Accessed December 24. https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/feminist_art_base/elizabeth-payne
Gentileschi Aegis Gallery Association. 2015. "Elizabeth Payne." Accessed December 24. https://gentileschiaegis.wordpress.com/elizabeth-payne-2/
Donor correspondence, 2015.
